meanings.sent1: She fadged the numbers to make it look like she had more sales.
meanings.sent2: He always fadged his resume to make himself seem more qualified.
meanings.sent3: The magician fadged the cards to trick the audience.
meanings.sent4: The student fadged his essay to avoid getting caught for plagiarism.
meanings.sent5: The detective knew the suspect had fadged the evidence to cover up the crime.

meanings.sent1: After a long day of work, she felt fadged and just wanted to relax.
meanings.sent2: The old car looked fadged with rust and peeling paint.
meanings.sent3: The tired puppy looked fadged after playing all day in the park.
meanings.sent4: The marathon runner crossed the finish line looking fadged but triumphant.
meanings.sent5: The fadged book had been read so many times, the pages were falling out.

meanings.definition: Fadged (adverb): in a tired or worn-out manner
meanings.sent1: She walked fadged to the finish line, exhausted from the race.
meanings.sent2: The old man moved fadged, with slow and deliberate steps.
meanings.sent3: The cat yawned fadged after a long nap in the sun.
meanings.sent4: The wind blew fadged through the trees, rustling the leaves.
meanings.sent5: The children played all day and returned home fadged, ready for bed.
